description: Extend the current permitted use (A2, A3, A5 or D1) to include C3 to facilitate conversion of unit into 2x bedroom residential apartment plus minor extenral alterations.
decision_conditions: The applicant has not demonstrated through sound evidence and rigorous marketing that there is no quantitative or qualitative need for a range of employment uses on site and has thereby failed to comply with the requirements of Policy DM17 (Protecting Existing Employment Land and Premises) of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012.

In the absence of a legal agreement to:- render the proposed unit "car free";- preclude future occupants from obtaining on-street car parking permits; and,- inform potential buyers/tenants of the above restrictions and to publicise the lack of parking provision in sales brochurethe proposals are considered to cause harm through increased traffic congestion and on-street car parking pressure and would have an adverse impact upon highway and pedestrian safety, thereby contravening LDF Core Strategy policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and DM10  (Design Requirements for New Developments (including House Extensions)) and the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013.

By reason of the insufficient floorspace the proposed unit would fail to provide a good standard of accommodation, thereby conflicting with Table 3.3 and Policy 3.5 (Quality and Design of Housing Developments) of the London Plan, 2016 and Policy DM10  (Design Requirements for New Developments (including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.

In the absence of an Air Quality Assessment and any mitigation measures contained therein, the applicant has failed to demonstrate that there would be no unacceptable adverse impact upon the future occupants of the residential unit in terms of air pollution as a result of the unit's proximity to London Road, thereby conflicting with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments (including House Extensions)).

In the absence of a Noise Assessment and any mitigation measures contained therein, the applicant has failed to demonstrate that there would be no unacceptable adverse impact upon the future occupants of the residential unit in terms of noise and distrubance as a result of the unit's proximity to London Road, thereby conflicting with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments (including House Extensions)).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Seven neighbouring properties have been notified and one objection has been received stating;- Access or traffic problems;- Car park issues;- Excessive height or bulk of buildings; and,- Inappropriate design/layout.The objection raising access problems relates to Party Wall issues and as such, is not a planning consideration.  An informative will be included to remind the applicant of their obligations to The Party Wall Act 1996.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on parking.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.  Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate two off street car parking spaces, which is acceptable in this case.  Therefore the proposal would comply with the Policy DM9 and DM10.In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Notwithstanding, it would serve as a proportionate and subordinate addition and would relate well to the main dwelling.  In addition, it is acknowledged that there are a variety of roof forms represented in the street.   Overall, Officers consider the proposed development to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. Therefore, there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area.Officers note that a Cetificate of Lawfulness 20/01616/CPU was issued on 03.09.2020 for the erection of a hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions with the installation of 3no front rooflights to the existing property.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Seven neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Whilst it is acknowledged that the proposal would exceed the recommended depths for single storey rear extensions as set out in the Council's Residential Design SPD, Officers do not consider that the proposal would be visually disproportionate given existing surrounding development. From a strictly character and design perspective, the proposed development is considered to be visually acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height and design. It is not considered that there would be any unacceptable adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals. The impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring properties is considered below.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Due to its excessive depth and width, leaving no separation distance from the shared boundaries, the proposal would fail the 45 degree rule in relation to the nearest ground floor habitable room window at adjoining No. 30 Deacon Road, resulting in an unacceptable loss of light, an undue sense of enclosure and loss of outlook and overbearing impact, thereby conflicting with Policy 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.In conclusion, the proposed development conflicts with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) and policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
